**Jeff Muller:**
(BTW, this is Jeff).  Feels like 2025 will turn out to be one where we focused on internal organizational development instead of making significant progress on identifying strategic opportunities at the HoldCo level.  Bringing in Max and Adam will be transformational if it improves delivery execution and leverages Bryon to focus on developing the relationships that will be necessary for strategic transactions.  Similarly, leveraging Jeff with additional contract admin (Christal) and financial modeling (new hire financial analyst) support will provide capacity to execute on strategic transactions.

**Carlo Viray:**
Of course I’m going to rate you best in grade for everything. You’re an amazing leader, mentor, and friend, and I’m all in for as long as you’ll have me and as long as I can keep contributing in a meaningful way.




The feedback I have isn’t really about you personally, but more about how I’ve been feeling lately and how those feelings show up in how I think about the company and how you empower the leadership team. Rise8 is definitely different now than it was when it was just me, you, and Matt — and then me and you — and then eventually the larger leadership group. I know you’re depending on me to lead Growth and to lead my people, and I take that seriously. But here are a few things I’m experiencing that I think are worth putting on your radar.




First, if Marketing and Growth are expected to have an intense focus on increasing qualified pipeline, then Growth is naturally going to rely a lot more on Delivery support in Q1 and Q2 until the Growth Solutions Team officially stands up. Right now it feels like we’re putting a pretty heavy demand on Delivery with the new request process. I worry that the combination of their capacity and our need for fast qualification is going to create bottlenecks. I literally had to create a ticketing system just to request support from Max. Maybe that’s what it needs to be, and I’m always open to experimenting, but it’s something I’m keeping an eye on.




Second, this one is more of a general feeling. As we get bigger and expand the leadership team and the operating model, it feels like we’re getting slower at decision-making. We end up in “whose lane is this” mode more than we used to, and then we spend a bunch of cycles figuring out who owns what and what the next steps are. A lot of it feels like it comes from two places: people being at capacity and not wanting to take on something ambiguous, and people wanting to protect their teams. The first point about Delivery support is a good example of that tension.




Third, I’m struggling to find A-player hires for Growth roles. I don’t know if it’s because we’re not sourcing enough candidates or attracting the right kind of people. I don’t know if I’m being too picky or if I’m scared to make the wrong hire. Or maybe part of me is afraid of giving up control to someone who thinks they can “do Growth better.” I’m trying to build this team in full alignment with how you and I see Growth and sales at Rise8, but it’s been tough, and I want to be honest about that. I don't want to let you down as we scale.

**Jordan Dilworth:**
The passion and intelligence is undeniable.  You learn the fastest, you commit to actions, keep it real.  You do have a tendency to be heavily influenced by others and this creates challenges in that your influences change because of the volume of content that you consume, and the influences, be it Hormozi, Scaling Up, Corporate Rebels, Evan Carmichael, Jeff Bezos Narrative Memo or others are not always consistent and we're always trying to apply their frameworks to Rise8.  I have seen a lot of maturity and growth in you as a leader and a person since I started.  Opportunities still exist for us as a team to be further aligned on the vision and strategy, think 3-year picture of what we look like, and spend more time growing the business.

**Kristin Pearson:**
I guess it's possible for a founder to not maximize every category, but I feel fortunate to have a CEO that truly walks the walk and sets the example for everyone.  I appreciate your integrity, intelligence, and vision.




I will say that sometimes I think all of us on the leadership team can get so focused on OIP and just getting the job done and hopefully displaying attributes like grit that we can forget things like gratitude.  I'm trying to remember to look for opportunities when expressing that is deserved, and I will say that in your position and coming from you, showing gratitude is extremely powerful.  I've seen how much that can mean to ICs, so just a nudge if helpful to remember this humble yet mighty tool in your leadership tool belt.  :)

**Adam Furtado:**
I'm so glad I made the jump to Rise8. I'm loving it and maintain the same fire I had on day 1.

**Max Reele:**
Interesting to answer about the CEO of the company, but to reframe, I would choose to work for you again and recommend other professionals I care about to work for you.

**Joseph Andrews:**
Yes, I would rehire Bryon as CEO ;-). I'll provide additional context in the next section but I appreciate his passion and directness. I believe he is a thoughtful leader and has a clear vision for the future of Rise8. There are always going to be growing pains when you double the size of a company in less than a year but Bryon is never shy to ask other for feedback or give his employees a platform to ask questions or give opinions, this is a rare quality.

**Mike Gehard:**
Bryon excels at setting bold vision and direction - the iRise videos are a perfect example of how his direct communication style rallies the company around our mission.




To maximize impact as we scale, I'd love to see more follow-through on strategic initiatives. For example, we introduced KPIs at Q2 offsite but pivoted at Q3 without closing out the originals. Establishing persistent KPIs with clear owners, regular check-ins, and visible tracking would help teams prioritize daily work and ensure initiatives reach completion.




While I appreciate the high-agency, low-rules environment, we need more horizontal structure (between teams) to support our growth - specifically explicit initiative owners and clearer accountability for cross-functional work like recruiting support.

**Jeff Wills:**
Seems like I mailed this one in, but I did spend a good bit of time reflecting on each one.  Bryon really does set the example in all Rise8 values. He doesn't just lead on paper; he leads in practice. 




iRise is always on point. He is there to support both teams and individuals whenever it's needed.  He doesn't prioritize the success of Rise8 to the detriment of A Players. He believes that the success of Rise8 is built on the success of our A players.




I think Byron sometimes holds back his opinion to let others have theirs, which is great. However, I believe there are situations where it would be helpful if he clearly communicated his opinions.




I sometimes git mixed signals from him on fire fast.  Bryon states fire fast frequently. However, I was ready to release some Risers (none for negligence, more so skills), and Bryon checked to see if I was sure. In one case, I kept the Riser.  This is a testament to Bryon's attention to the human element, but it does make me second-guess myself. Am I moving too slowly? Am I moving too fast? Always good questions to consider, but it makes it hard to know if I'm doing a good job on this front.




Bryon's drive and passion for some topics can create anxiety in some Risers because they don't understand the whole picture or what it will look like in practice.  I know some of the early sharing comes from the passion and vision he has for the future, which I appreciate.  I believe Byron's past performance in these areas should instill confidence that it will be beneficial for both the Riser and Rise8.  A Player scoreboard, as an example, is creating some anxiety in the masses.  I think there are questions about whether this is going to be public to all Risers?  Will A player's score take into account my Level, i.e., will I be ranked lower simply because a level above me contributes more? How will this work when I'm on a study or working a difficult client that we though was a good fit but infact wasn't?  Having a more detailed plan or a list of factors to consider before mentioning a "big" change will help Risers adapt more easily.  They often bring baggage from past employers that results in an anxiety response instead of a reflective response.  Byron's leadership and Rise8 have done right by us in the past and are likely to do so again.

**Matt Pacione:**
From Matt Pacione




I would absolutely "rehire" Bryon to work on "my team" in the same role. Bryon's vision and passion for mission impact and making the world a better place is very encouraging and influential in the space in which we work. I love that he breaks the norm on what GovTech has done in the past for the sake and benefit of the warfighter and veteran. He cares for his team unlike any other CEO that I've worked for and it's wonderful to know that he's willing and ready to do anything for his teammates. He shares out what it's like from a CEO's perspective but also gets down to earth on a personal level and genuinely works with the teams to help delivery and remove any major issues. He tackles major problems for the teams and looks out for them and the customer all the time.

**Brian Jennings:**
I love the organization you've built and are building and the big ambitious vision you have for us. I appreciate the dedication to outcomes, so much so than planning revolves around the impact we can create rather than the revenue we can generate. I love your open door policy for everyone, your candor and perspective when you share feedback with folks. I'm inspired by your thirst for growth, reading and wanting to be the best at everything. It sets the tone for the whole organization.

**Rob Monroe:**
- What we do, where we are heading, and with your leadership compass, is still the reason why I am at Rise8
- Your radical candor and transparency are truly unique, please don't ever pull away from this
- It's incredible to see how you're able to chip in and support so many different individuals and teams all at once. I seriously don't understand how you manage it all.
- **Do what works** is the only thing that I'd like you to consider making an adjustment going forward. 
   - Even when we're certain that something is a root cause, contributing factor, or the solution we need, we should leverage those as opportunities to demonstrate what good looks like to Riser IC's and department leads. 
   - In recent months I haven't seen the leadership team as a whole demonstrating a curiosity-led approach with hypotheses that leverage data-backed decisions for solution, outcome and impact bets. 
   - Not doing this increases the risk of delivery teams wondering why they're held to a different standard. We can't just stop at we're doing xyz because it's obvious, or to just trust us, because we would never accept that from our delivery teams. If you believe we are doing these things well today, then I'd ask that we at least adjust our communication about these efforts. I like the OPSP for what it is, but it doesn't provide data or insights that led to certain constraints being prioritized over others or the hypothesis around a particular solution we're betting on over others. That clarity and transparency raises trust, engagement and willing support - things that get harder as we get bigger.

**Jennifer Lopez:**
Bryon is a high-velocity, mission-driven leaders whose strengths in transparency, growth mindset, and rapid execution drive meaningful momentum for Rise8. There are opportunities to deepen alignment around user-validated impact, refine coaching-on-the-fly moments, and apply CEO-level leverage that motivates and stabilizes the team. Overall, his intent, integrity, and pace of improvement remain standout strengths.
